Know and understand ‘Windrush’ and Caribbean migrants: reasons for migration, experiences, and impact on British society.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Claudia Jones and her work in the UK
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand the work of Claudia Jones in the UK and her significance in shaping Caribbean community identity and anti-racism activism.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Migration from Asia and Africa; Amin in Uganda
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand post-war migration from Asia and Africa, including the role of Amin in Uganda in driving refugee migration to the UK.
Know and understand the Commonwealth: what it was, why it developed, and its significance for Britain’s post-imperial relationships and migration.
Know and understand the Falklands War as part of the legacy of empire: causes, significance for national identity and international relations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Post-WWII Europe relationship: economic, social and cultural interaction
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand Britain’s relationship with Europe after WWII, including economic, social and cultural interaction and their impact on Britain.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: End of the Cold War and EU membership
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand how the end of the Cold War and membership of the European Union affected Britain, including politics, economy and identity debates.
Know and understand patterns of European and non-European migration to Britain in the late 20th century and beyond, including causes and impacts.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Death of Edward the Confessor and succession crisis
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand the death of Edward the Confessor and why it created a succession crisis leading to the Norman Conquest.
Know and understand the main claimants to the English throne in 1066 and the basis of their claims.
Know and understand the Battle of Stamford Bridge: causes, events, and significance in the 1066 campaign.
Know and understand the Battle of Hastings: causes, events, tactics, and significance.
Know and understand key Anglo-Saxon military tactics used in 1066 and strengths/weaknesses.
Know and understand key Norman military tactics used in 1066 and why they were effective.
Know and understand the use of cavalry as a Norman military innovation and how it affected battlefield outcomes.
Know and understand the use of castles as a military innovation: purposes in conquest/control, and how they changed warfare and power.
Know and understand the Harrying of the North: reasons, actions, and consequences for control and population.
Know and understand revolts against Norman rule (1067–1075): causes, key events, and outcomes.
Know and understand William I’s leadership and government methods for maintaining control, including administration and delegation.
Know and understand William II’s inheritance of the throne and key features of his rule relevant to continuity/change from William I.
Know and understand feudalism in Norman England: roles, rights, and responsibilities within the feudal hierarchy.
Know and understand landholding and lordship under the Normans and how land control underpinned power.
Know and understand how land was redistributed after 1066 and its consequences for Anglo-Saxon elites and Norman control.
Know and understand patronage in Norman government (rewards, loyalty) and how it helped secure control.
Know and understand similarities/differences between Anglo-Saxon and Norman government systems (continuity and change in administration).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Anglo-Saxon vs Norman aristocracies and societies
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand how aristocracy and society changed after 1066, including displacement of Anglo-Saxon elites and formation of Norman ruling class.
Know and understand military service obligations under the feudal system and how this supported Norman rule.
Know and understand Norman justice and the legal system, including ordeals as a method of trial and beliefs underpinning them.
Know and understand the ‘murdrum’ fine: what it was, why introduced, and what it indicates about Norman control and tensions.
Know and understand inheritance practices in Norman England and how they affected landholding and power.
Know and understand the Domesday Book: why compiled, what it recorded, and its significance for government, taxation, and control.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Anglo-Saxon and Norman life: towns and villages
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand everyday life in towns and villages under Anglo-Saxon and Norman rule, including continuity and change after conquest.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Anglo-Saxon and Norman buildings and material culture
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand buildings/material life (architecture, housing, churches, castles) and how these reflected social and cultural change under the Normans.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Work, food, roles and seasonal life
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand work, food, roles (gender/status) and seasonal patterns of life in Norman England.
Know and understand Forest law: what it was, why introduced/expanded, and its social/economic consequences.
Know and understand key features of the Anglo-Saxon Church before 1066 and its role in society and governance.
Know and understand the role of Archbishop Lanfranc and reforms of the English Church, including changes to organisation and discipline.
Know and understand Norman church/cathedral building: reasons (power, piety, reform) and significance for culture and authority.
Know and understand Church organisation and courts in Norman England and how Church law interacted with royal government.
Know and understand Church–state relations under William I and William II, including cooperation, conflict, and control over appointments/wealth.
Know and understand the wealth of the Church and how it affected power, politics, and society in Norman England.
Know and understand Norman relations with the Papacy and how papal authority influenced English Church and politics.
Know and understand the Investiture Controversy: what it was, why it mattered in Europe, and its relevance to Norman England.
Know and understand Norman reforms to monasticism, including building of abbeys/monasteries and their purposes.
Know and understand monastic life: routines, vows, economic role, and influence on society.
Know and understand how monasteries and the Church supported learning, schools and education in Norman England.
Know and understand the use of Latin and the vernacular in Norman England and what this reveals about culture, administration, and learning.

Topics.Topic_name: BB Medieval England: the reign of Edward I, 1272–1307

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Henry III’s legacy and Edward’s accession problems
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand Henry III’s legacy, Edward’s relationship with his father, problems faced on Edward I’s accession, and how these shaped early rule.
Know and understand Edward I’s relations with the nobility: cooperation/conflict and how Edward managed noble power.
Know and understand Edward I’s character as a king and how personality/leadership influenced government and policy.
Know and understand the Hundred Rolls: purpose, what they investigated, and significance for government/justice.
Know and understand the role of Robert Burnell in Edward I’s government and reforms.
Know and understand the Statutes of Westminster: aims, key features, and significance for law and governance.
Know and understand the Statutes of Mortmain: aims (land/Church wealth control) and impact.
Know and understand the ‘Quo Warranto’ inquiries: purpose, targets, and significance for royal authority and rights.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Edward I’s parliaments and Model Parliament (1295)
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand Edward I’s use of parliaments, including the Model Parliament (1295): composition, purpose, and impact on representation.
Know and understand agriculture and the wool trade in Medieval England and how they shaped economy and society.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Royal finance and taxation; wool tax
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand royal finance and taxation, including the wool tax: why used and effects on economy and politics.
Know and understand the Statute of Merchants: aims, how it worked, and its impact on trade and finance.
Know and understand the role of Italian bankers in royal finance and the risks/benefits of reliance on credit.
Know and understand re-coinage under Edward I: why carried out and its economic significance.
Know and understand the expulsion of the Jews in 1290: causes, context (finance/anti-Jewish sentiment), and consequences.
Know and understand the role of the medieval Church and universities in education and learning in Edward I’s reign.
Know and understand key thinkers Roger Bacon and Duns Scotus and what they indicate about medieval learning and intellectual change.
Know and understand the development of the legal system: laws, courts, trials, and how justice was administered in medieval England.
Know and understand types of crimes, who committed them, and punishments used; understand what this reveals about order and authority.
Know and understand the Statute of Gloucester (1278): purpose and significance for law/justice.
Know and understand the Statute of Winchester (1285): purpose and significance for law/order (policing, keeping the peace).
Know and understand medieval warfare tactics and technology, including siege warfare and its role in Edward I’s campaigns.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Medieval warfare: cavalry and infantry use
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand battlefield use of cavalry and infantry in medieval warfare and why different forces mattered.
Know and understand key weapons and armour and how technology affected combat effectiveness.
Know and understand Edward’s Welsh Wars (1277 and 1282–1283): causes, key events, and outcomes.
Know and understand the Statute of Rhuddlan: what it established and how it changed governance of Wales.
Know and understand Edward’s castle building programme in Wales: purpose, design as control, and significance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Costs and consequences of Welsh conquest
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand the costs and consequences of conquest and colonisation of Wales for England and Wales.
Know and understand ‘the Great Cause’: the Scottish succession dispute and why Edward became involved.
Know and understand the roles of Balliol and Bruce in the Scottish succession and conflicts with Edward I.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Scottish campaigns and First War of Scottish Independence (1297–1307)
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand Edward I’s Scottish campaigns and the First War of Scottish Independence from 1297 to Edward’s death: key events and outcomes.
Know and understand the role and significance of William Wallace in Scottish resistance and the war against Edward I.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Edward I as ‘Hammer of the Scots’ (reputation)
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand why Edward I gained the reputation ‘Hammer of the Scots’ and evaluate how far it is justified.
Know and understand Elizabeth I’s background and character and how these influenced her style of rule and decision-making.
Know and understand Elizabethan court life, including patronage systems, factions, and how power was exercised through the court.
Know and understand the role of key ministers (eg Cecil, Walsingham where relevant) and how they supported Elizabeth’s government.
Know and understand relations between Elizabeth and Parliament: areas of cooperation/conflict and limits on royal authority.
Know and understand the problem of marriage and succession and why it created political tension and risk in Elizabethan England.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Strength of Elizabeth’s authority by 1603 (Essex’s rebellion)
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand the strength of Elizabeth’s authority at the end of her reign, including causes, events and significance of Essex’s rebellion (1601).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Living standards and fashions; ‘Golden Age’ claim
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand living standards and fashions in Elizabethan England and evaluate the idea of a ‘Golden Age’.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Growing prosperity and rise of the gentry
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand causes of growing prosperity and the rise of the gentry and how this changed social structure and politics.
Know and understand achievements of Elizabethan theatre and contemporary attitudes toward the theatre (moral/religious concerns).
Know and understand reasons for increased poverty in Elizabethan England (population growth, inflation, unemployment, enclosure).
Know and understand attitudes to the poor and responses to poverty (local charity, punishment, poor relief) and how views changed.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Government action on poverty: reasons and seriousness
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand reasons for government action on poverty and how serious the problem was perceived to be.
Know and understand the roles of Hawkins and Drake as English sailors/explorers and how they contributed to trade, conflict and expansion.
Know and understand Drake’s circumnavigation (1577–1580): aims, achievements, and significance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Voyages and trade; role of Raleigh
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand voyages and trade expansion, including the role of Raleigh, and how exploration linked to wealth and rivalry.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Religious settlement tensions: Catholicism vs Protestantism
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand the question of religion in Elizabethan England, including tensions between English Catholicism and Protestantism and challenges to the Elizabethan settlement.
Know and understand the Northern Rebellion: causes, events, and consequences for security and religious policy.
Know and understand Elizabeth’s excommunication: why it happened and consequences for Catholic plots and foreign threats.
Know and understand the role of Catholic missionaries (priests/Jesuits): aims, activities, and government response.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Catholic plots and threat to settlement
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand Catholic plots against Elizabeth and how they threatened the Elizabethan settlement (security and succession).
Know and understand the nature and ideas of Puritans and Puritanism and why they challenged the Church settlement.
Know and understand Elizabeth and her government’s policies and responses to religious matters, including enforcement and compromise.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mary Queen of Scots: background and threat
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand Mary Queen of Scots’ background and why she posed a challenge to Elizabeth (succession, religion, plots).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Treatment of Mary by Elizabeth and Parliament
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand how Elizabeth and Parliament treated Mary Queen of Scots and how policy changed over time.
Know and understand plots involving Mary Queen of Scots and the events leading to her execution; explain impact of execution.
Know and understand reasons for conflict with Spain (religious, trade, Netherlands, piracy) and escalation to war.
Know and understand naval warfare tactics and technology in the Elizabethan period and how they influenced outcomes against Spain.
Know and understand events leading to and during the defeat of the Spanish Armada and its significance for England and Europe.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Legacy of Civil War and Commonwealth
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand the legacy of the English Civil War and Commonwealth and how it shaped politics at the Restoration.
Know and understand the restoration of the monarchy in 1660: why it happened and immediate political settlement.
Know and understand the succession issue during Charles II’s reign and why it caused political instability.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Charles II and Parliament: finance and religion issues
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand relations and issues with Parliament, including finance and religion, and how these affected governance under Charles II.
Know and understand the Cabal ministry and the development of ‘party politics’ and why factions emerged.
Know and understand Charles II’s rule without Parliament from 1681: why it occurred and consequences for power and policy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Titus Oates and the Popish Plot
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand Titus Oates and the Popish Plot: accusations, hysteria, and political consequences.
Know and understand the Rye House Plot: aims, events, and consequences for opposition and repression.
Know and understand the Exclusion Bill (1679): aims, debates, and significance for monarchy, Parliament and party development.
Know and understand the role of James, Duke of York in the Catholic question and succession crisis in Charles II’s reign.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Charles II’s character and court life
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand Charles II’s character, court life and fashions, and how the court influenced politics and culture.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Great Plague (1665): causes and contemporary views
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand the Great Plague of 1665: causes as understood at the time and contemporary views/explanations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Great Plague measures, records and results
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand measures to combat the Great Plague, how it was recorded, and results/impact on society.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Fire of London (1666): causes and contemporary views
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand the Fire of London of 1666: causes and contemporary views/explanations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Fire of London: results and reconstruction
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand results of the Fire of London and reconstruction efforts, including changes to building and city planning.
Know and understand Restoration culture including Restoration comedy, theatres and playwrights and why theatre culture changed after 1660.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Role and status of women (Restoration culture)
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand the role and status of women in Restoration England, including cultural changes (eg actresses) and limits.
Know and understand coffee houses: their role in social, political and commercial life and why they were significant.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Royal Society and patronage of arts/sciences
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand Charles II’s patronage of the arts and sciences, including the Royal Society and significance for scientific progress.
Know and understand Samuel Pepys’ significance as a source and figure of Restoration London life and administration.
Know and understand Restoration architecture and design, including Christopher Wren’s role in rebuilding and cultural change.
Know and understand the powers of the East India Company and how they supported English expansion and trade.
Know and understand the significance of Bombay in Restoration-era expansion/trade and how it was acquired/used.
Know and understand the significance of Hudson Bay in trade/empire (fur trade, chartered companies) during the Restoration period.
Know and understand the significance of Tangier as a strategic possession and why it mattered for trade/naval power.
Know and understand Captain Henry Morgan and Jamaica: piracy/privateering, imperial competition, and Caribbean power.
Know and understand mercantilism: key ideas and how it shaped trade and colonial policy.
Know and understand the Navigation Acts: purpose, provisions, and impact on trade and international relations.
Know and understand the slave trade in the Restoration period and how it linked to trade, colonies, and wealth.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: English sea power and naval warfare tactics/technology
Sub_topics.description: Know and understand English sea power and naval warfare, including tactics and technology and their role in conflict and empire.
Know and understand causes, events, and consequences of the Second Dutch War within Restoration foreign policy.
Know and understand causes, events, and consequences of the Third Dutch War and how it affected trade and politics.
Know and understand Restoration England’s relations with Spain and France and how diplomacy and rivalry affected war and trade.
